questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to your clinic with a painful limp and difficulty walking for the past few weeks. Examination shows an antalgic gait, limited internal rotation of the hip, and slight leg-length discrepancy on the affected side.Based on this presentation, which of the following conditions is least likely to be the cause of his painful limp?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital Coxa Vara produce painless limping in a child

The only 2 conditions that produce painless limping in a child are:

  1. Congenital coxa vara
  2. Early stage of Perthe's disease. In later stages, Perthe's disease will also become painful.

Congenital Coxa Vara

Congenital coxa vara is a developmental condition in which the neck-shaft angle of the femur is abnormally reducedto less than 120° (normal ≈ 135° in children), resulting in a varus deformity of the proximal femur.

Age of Presentation:

  • Usually presents in early childhood (1-3 years)
  • Can be present at birth or detected after walking begins

Etiology:

  • Often idiopathic
  • May be associated with:
    • Skeletal dysplasias
    • Metabolic bone disease
    • Occasionally familial

Clinical Features:

  • Painless limp is the most common symptom
  • Shortening of the affected limb
  • Restricted hip abduction and internal rotation
  • Adduction and external rotation deformity
  • Trendelenburg gait due to weak hip abductors
  • No significant pain unless secondary complications arise

Physical Examination:

  • Apparent limb length discrepancy
  • Positive Trendelenburg sign
  • Limited abduction and internal rotation

Radiographic Features:

  • Decreased neck-shaft angle (<120°)
  • Triangular fragment at the inferior femoral neck (Fairbank's triangle)
  • Delayed ossification of the femoral head
  • Vertical orientation of the physis
  • Increased Hilgenreiner's angle

Treatment:

Surgical Options:

  • Corrective valgus osteotomy of the proximal femur (to restore neck-shaft angle)
  • Sometimes combined with epiphysiodesis of the greater trochanter to improve abductor function

Explanation of Other Options:

SCFE (Option A): Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis

  • Occurs in adolescents, usually during growth spurts.
  • Presents with a painful limp, hip or referred knee pain, and limited internal rotation.
  • Radiographs show displacement of the femoral epiphysis

TB of the Hip (Option B):

  • Chronic infection presenting with painful limp, restricted motion, and systemic symptoms.
  • Radiographic findings can include joint space narrowing, bone destruction, and pain on weight-bearing .

Perthes' Disease (Option C):

  • Avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children aged 4-10.
  • Symptoms include limp (often painful), restricted hip motion, and radiographic signs like coxa plana and sclerosis

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a painless limp since early childhood. On examination, there is restricted abduction and internal rotation of the hip, and the limb is held in adduction and external rotation. Radiographs show a decreased neck-shaft angle (<120°) of the femur. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario and the radiological finding given the most probable diagnosis would be Coxa Vara. Telescoping of hip is not seen in this condition.

  • Telescoping of the hip refers to a false mobility or piston-like movement of the femur into the pelvis when axial pressure is applied on the flexed thigh. It is a sign of hip joint instability.
  • Telescoping of hip is seen in unstable hip and not in coxa vara. Causes of telescopy can be DDH, Tom Smith arthritis, surgical excision of femoral head etc.

Telescopy Test:

  1. The patient lies supine.
  2. The hip and knee are flexed to 90 degrees.
  3. The examiner pushes the femur gently downward toward the pelvis and then pulls upward.
  4. A positive test is when the femoral head moves abnormally in and out of the acetabulum, like a piston.

Explanation of Other Options:

Axis Deviation (Option A):

  • Seen in coxa vara
  • Due to the varus angulation of the proximal femur, the mechanical axis of the limb deviates medially.
  • Contributes to gait disturbances.

Trendelenburg Sign (Option B):

  • Common in coxa vara
  • The decreased neck-shaft angle reduces the abductor lever arm, leading to gluteus medius weakness.
  • This results in a positive Trendelenburg sign during single-leg stance.

Adduction and External Rotation Deformity (Option D):

  • Characteristic finding
  • Due to the altered femoral neck orientation, the limb is often held in adduction and external rotation.
  • Contributes to functional limb shortening and abnormal gait.

questions.text: A 7 year old child presented with limping for 1 month. X-ray shows fragmentation of femoral capital epiphysis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fragmentation of femoral capital epiphysis is seen in Perthe's disease.
  • Perthe's disease is an idiopathic reversible avascular necrosis of femoral capital epiphysis in a child.
  • Seen in children between 4-8 years
  • These children present with painless limp initially which progresses to painful limp over time.
  • X ray findings include:
    • Fragmentation of femoral capital epiphysis
    • Collapse of the epiphysis
    • Crescent sign - due to subchondral collapse
  • Treatment
    • Child is put on non weight bearing till revascularization occurs.
    • Petrie's/broomstick cast is sometimes used

Explanation of Other Options:

Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) (Option B):

  • Usually diagnosed in infancy or early childhood, not at 7 years.
  • Classic signs: asymmetric thigh folds, limb shortening, positive Ortolani/Barlow signs (infants).
  • In older untreated cases: limp, waddling gait, leg-length discrepancy.
  • X-ray: Dislocated femoral head, shallow acetabulum-not epiphyseal fragmentation.

Tuberculosis of the Hip (Option C):

  • Common in developing countries.
  • Presents with painful limp, systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss).
  • X-ray findings: Joint space narrowing, periarticular osteoporosis, bony erosions, subluxation or dislocation-not fragmentation of the epiphysis.
  • Much slower onset, and the child often appears ill.

Congenital Coxa Vara (Option D):

  • Typically presents earlier (1-3 years) with a painless limp.
  • Due to decreased neck-shaft angle of the femur (<120°).
  • X-ray shows: Short femoral neck, vertical physis, no fragmentation.
  • The deformity is mechanical, not vascular or infectious.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a painless limp and occasional hip discomfort. Radiographs show fragmentation of the femoral capital epiphysis, with some lateral subluxation and metaphyseal changes. Which of the following is not a poor prognostic sign of the given condition
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The poor prognostic signs of Perthe's disease are called Head at risk signs.
  • Head at risk signs are
    • Gage sign - V shaped radiolucency in the lateral aspect of the physis.
    • Calcification lateral to epiphysis
    • Horizontal physis
    • Lateral subluxation of the femoral head
    • Metaphyseal cysts
  • Separation of physis is a feature of SCFE and no Perthe's disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lateral Subluxation (Option A)

  • A classic "head-at-risk" sign.
  • Indicates loss of containment in the acetabulum, associated with poor remodeling and increased risk of deformity

Metaphyseal Cysts (Option B)

  • Occur during the fragmentation stage, often adjacent to the growth plateWhile their prognostic value is debated, many studies link them with increased femoral neck involvement and adverse deformity .

Calcification Lateral to the Physis (Option C)

  • Represents healing or revascularization-commonly seen during reossification.
  • Although a "head-at-risk" criterion (by Catterall), it often indicates recovery rather than severity
  • Therefore, not a poor prognostic sign.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy, a known case of hypothyroidism, presents with acute-onset left hip pain and an inability to bear weight. His weight is 70 kg. On examination, his left lower limb is held in a position of external rotation and adduction. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE). This is a condition where the femoral head (epiphysis) displaces posteriorly and inferiorly relative to the femoral neck through the growth plate. The clinical picture is classic for SCFE.

  • Age and Gender: The patient is a 12-year-old male, placing him directly in the typical peri-pubertal age group (10-16 years) for SCFE.
  • Risk Factors: He has two major risk factors: obesity (70 kg is significantly overweight for a 12-year-old) and hypothyroidism, the most common endocrinopathy associated with SCFE.
  • Clinical Presentation: The acute inability to walk suggests an unstable slip, and the classic position of the limb held in external rotation and adduction is pathognomonic.

Explanation of Other Options:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (Option A): Perthes' disease is an avascular necrosis of the femoral head typically seen in a younger age group (4 to 10 years). The clinical presentation is usually a chronic, painless limp.

Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) (Option B): DDH is a condition diagnosed in infancy or early childhood. Presentation at this age with acute pain is highly atypical; it usually presents as a painless limp or gait abnormality.

Septic Arthritis (Option D): While septic arthritis presents with acute pain and inability to bear weight, the patient would typically have systemic signs of infection, such as fever. The position of comfort for septic arthritis of the hip is usually flexion, abduction, and external rotation to maximize joint volume, not adduction.

Key Takeaways: Differentiating Pediatric Hip Pain

questions.text: X ray (AP view) of bilateral hip is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The radiograph shows positive Trethoven's sign
  • Trethoven's sign is positive in Slipped capital femoral epiphysis.
  • For understanding Trethoven's sign, first we need to learn about Klein's line.
  • Klein's line is just a straight line drawn along the upper border of the neck of femur.
  • Normally the Klein's line should pass through the capital femoral epiphysis.
  • In SCFE, the Klein's line will not pass through the capital femoral epiphysis. This is called the Trethoven's sign.

Explanation of Other Options:

Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH) (Option B):

Radiological Features:

  • In infants/children:
    • Dislocated femoral head (located superior and lateral to the acetabulum)
    • Shallow acetabulum
    • Delayed ossification of the femoral head
  • Use Hilgenreiner's line, Perkin's line, and Shenton's line to assess:
    • Disruption of Shenton's line
    • Femoral head lies outside the inferomedial quadrant of the acetabulum
  • No Trethowan's sign involvement

Perthes'Disease (Legg-Calve-Perthes Disease) (Option C):

Radiological Features:

  • Occurs in children aged 4-10
  • Stages on X-ray (Waldenström classification):
    1. Initial: Smaller femoral head, increased joint space
    2. Fragmentation: Irregular, broken-down ossific nucleus
    3. Reossification: Gradual restoration
    4. Healed: May be deformed (mushroom-shaped)
  • No positive Trethowan's sign
  • May show crescent sign (subchondral fracture)

Tuberculosis of the Hip (Option D):

Radiological Features:

  • Seen in children or adults with systemic symptoms (weight loss, fever)
  • Classic Phemister's triad:
    1. Periarticular osteoporosis
    2. Joint space narrowing
    3. Peripheral bony erosions
  • May also see subluxation, destruction of femoral head, or acetabular involvement
  • No relevance to Klein's line or Trethowan's sign

questions.text: Congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia is commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neurofibromatosis is commonly associated with Congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia

  • Congenital pseudoarthrosis of tibia is the congenital bowing of tibia due to a diaphyseal defect which fails to unite due to abnormal bone tissue at the site.
  • Cause: unknown
  • MC association: Neurofibromatosis
  • It causes anterolateral bowing of tibia
  • Occurs in 2-4% of patients with NF1.
  • X-ray: Thinning, tapering, sclerosis, and cortical thickening of tibia, often with a narrowed medullary canal.

Explanation of Other Options:

Tuberous Sclerosis(Option B)

  • A neurocutaneous disorder characterized by:
    • Cortical tubers in the brain
    • Adenoma sebaceum
    • Renal angiomyolipomas
  • Not associated with bone pseudoarthrosis.

Arthrogryposis Multiplex Congenita (Option C)

  • Congenital condition with multiple joint contractures present at birth.
  • Characterized by fibrosis of muscles and soft tissues, leading to stiff joints.
  • Does not involve pseudoarthrosis of the tibia.

Poliomyelitis (Option D)

  • A viral infection causing motor neuron destruction, leading to flaccid paralysis and muscle atrophy.
  • Late sequelae can include limb deformity, shortening, and subluxation, but not pseudoarthrosis.

questions.text: A 2 month old baby is brought to the OPD with asymmetric thigh folds. The examiner performs flexion and abduction of hip resulting in a click. Which test was done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The test described in the question is Ortolani test

  • Asymmetric thigh folds indicate that the child is suffering from developmental dysplasia of hip (DDH).
  • In DDH, when the examiner abducts and flexes the hip, it will get reduced. And when the femoral head goes into the acetabulum, it produces a click sound. This is called the click of entry. This test where we reduce the hip and get a click of entry is called the Ortolani test.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Barlow Test (Option B):
  • Purpose: To detect a reducible hip that can be dislocated.
  • Method: With hips flexed, adduct the thigh and apply gentle posterior pressure.
  • Positive Sign: A sensation of the femoral head slipping out posteriorly → indicates instability.
  • Mnemonic: "Barlow pushes the hip out", "Ortolani brings it back in."

Klisic Test (Option A):

  • Purpose: To check for hip position asymmetry.
  • Method: Place one finger on the greater trochanter and the other on the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS). A line is drawn between them.
  • Positive sign: If the line passes below the umbilicus, it suggests a dislocated hip.
  • No click is elicited, only alignment is checked.

Alli's Test (also known as Galeazzi sign) (Option D):

  • Purpose: To check for femoral shortening.
  • Method: With baby supine and hips/knees flexed, look at knee heights.
  • Positive sign: One knee is lower → indicates femoral shortening due to dislocated hip or congenital shortening.
  • Again, no click is elicited.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought for a well-child visit. The mother notes asymmetrical thigh creases, and on examination, there is limited abduction of the left hip. An AP X-ray of the pelvis is obtained, revealing the findings shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis is Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH). The clinical findings of asymmetrical thigh folds and limited hip abduction in an infant are highly suggestive of DDH.

The provided X-ray confirms the diagnosis. Key features include:

  • The patient is skeletally immature (open physes).
  • There is superolateral dislocation of the left femoral head relative to the shallow acetabulum.
  • The normal smooth arc of Shenton's line is disrupted on the left side.

Explanation of Other Options:

Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE) (Option A): SCFE is a condition of adolescents (typically 10-16 years old) where the femoral head slips posteroinferiorly. It is not seen in infants.

Legg-Calvé-Perthes Disease (Option C): Perthes' disease is an avascular necrosis of the femoral head that affects children aged 4-10 years. Radiographs would show sclerosis, fragmentation, and flattening of the femoral epiphysis, not a dislocation.

Coxa Vara (Option D): Coxa vara refers to a decreased femoral neck-shaft angle (<120°). While it can cause a limp, it does not involve the dislocation of the femoral head from the acetabulum.

Key Takeaways: Differentiating Pediatric Hip Disorders

choices.text: Hour glass constriction of capsule by Iliopsoas tendon

questions.text: Which of the following is not a block for the closed reduction of DDH?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Small femoral head is not a block for the closed reduction of DDH

  • The first line of treatment of DDH is closed reduction of the hip and maintenance of the reduction with braces or casts.
  • Sometimes closed reduction may not be possible and the doctor may have to go for an open reduction of the hip.
  • The cause for the failure of closed reduction are called 'blocks of reduction'.
  • Blocks of reduction are:
    • Inverted Limbus - in turned labrum( Option A ruled out)
    • Pulvinar - fibrous tissue filling the acetabulum
    • Hypertrophic Ligamentum Teres(Option C ruled out)
    • Hour glass constriction of capsule by Iliopsoas tendon( Option D ruled out)
    • Transverse Acetabular Ligament

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the pediatric orthopedic clinic for evaluation of an abnormal position of the right knee noted at birth. There is no history of trauma. X-ray confirms anterior displacement of the tibia in relation to the femur.What is the most likely clinical presentation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario the most probable diagnosis id Congenital knee dislocation and the most likely clinical presentation would be Genu recurvatum.

  • Congenital dislocation of knee presents as severe genu recurvatum.

Genu recurvatum

  • Genu recurvatum is the pathological hyperextension of knee.
  • May be associated with conditions like arthrogryposis, Larsen syndrome, or spina bifida.

Etiology in Children:


Explanation of Other Options:

Genu varum (bow legs)(Option A):

  • Seen in physiologic bowing, Blount's disease, or rickets.
  • Not characteristic of congenital knee dislocation.

Genu valgum (knock-knees) (Option B):

  • More commonly associated with rickets, post-traumatic deformity, or skeletal dysplasia.

Windswept knee (Option D):

  • One leg in valgus and the other in varus.
  • Seen in skeletal dysplasia or neuromuscular disorders, not in isolated congenital knee dislocation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the orthopedic clinic by parents concerned about the child's knock-knees. The deformity has been progressively worsening over the past year. Which is the most common cause of this condition ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical scenario the most probable condition would be genu valgum

  • The most common cause of genu valgum in a child is idiopathic followed by rickets.
  • As there is no 'idiopathic' in the options, rickets is the best answer.

Rickets:

  • Nutritional rickets leads to defective mineralization of the growth plate.
  • Causes softening of bones, leading to angular deformities like genu valgum or sometimes genu varum, depending on age and severity.
  • Common between ages 3-7 years.
  • Lab clues: ↓ calcium, ↓ phosphate, ↑ ALP, ↑ PTH
  • X-ray: Cupping, fraying, widening of the metaphysis
  • Causes of genu valgum is given in the table.

Explanation of Other Options:

Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis (JRA) (Option B):

  • Can cause joint deformities, but genu valgum is not the most typical early presentation.
  • More often causes joint stiffness, swelling, and contractures.

Trauma (Option C):

  • Trauma to the growth plate (Salter-Harris injuries) can lead to angular deformities.
  • But it's a less common and usually unilateral cause of genu valgum.

Blount's Disease (Option D):

  • Affects the proximal tibial physis, causing genu varum (bow legs), not valgum.
  • It is the opposite deformity.

choices.text: Defect in posterior medial upper tibial physis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Blount's disease ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vicker's ligament is not a feature of Blount's disease

  • Vicker's ligament is seen in Madelung deformity and not in Blount's disease.
  • It is a fibrous band extending from the distal radius to the ulna, which tethers the growth plate and causes wrist deformity.
  • Blount's disease is Infantile Tibia Vara.
  • It is an idiopathic osteochondrolysis of medial proximal tibial physis and epiphysis in a child, resulting in progressive genu varum.( Option B ruled out)

Types (by Age of Onset):

Pathophysiology:

  • Growth suppression in the posteromedial proximal tibial physis.
  • Leads to asymmetric tibial growth, medial beaking, and varus deformity.
  • Clinical features
    • Bow legs( Option A ruled out)
    • Siffert Katz sign - abnormal gait in Blount's disease( Option C ruled out)
  • X-ray findings
    • Metaphyseal beaking
    • Metaphyseo diaphyseal angle of Drennan > 11°

questions.text: The following foot deformity is seen in all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows Rocker bottom foot

  • Rocker bottom is not seen in triple arthrodesis.
  • Triple arthrodesis is a surgical procedure involving fusion of the subtalar, talonavicular, and calcaneocuboid joints.
  • It is commonly performed in neglected or resistant cases of CTEV, especially in older children and adolescents, to correct deformities and provide a stable, plantigrade foot.

Rocker bottom foot

  • Rocker bottom foot is where the sole of the foot is convex like the bottom of a rocking chair.
  • It can be seen in
    1. Congenital vertical talus: the classic cause, due to dorsolateral dislocation of the navicular bone on the talus.( Option A ruled out)
    2. Over correction of CTEV: iatrogenic, when excessive dorsiflexion is forced during treatment, especially in surgical correction or bracing.( Option B ruled out)
    3. Arthrogryposis: due to severe rigid equinovalgus or equinovarus deformities with soft-tissue contractures.( Option C ruled out)

questions.text: An 1 month old child presents with equino-cavo-varus deformity of right foot. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Equino-cavo-varus deformity is seen in CTEV.
  • The treatment of choice of any child with CTEV less than 1 year of age is serial casting using the Ponseti technique.

Management of CTEV

  1. Manipulation alone ("mother's method")
    • Description: Parents are taught to dorsiflex and evert the infant's foot for 5 minutes after each feed. Each stretch is held for about 5 seconds.
    • Indication: Suitable for mild/supple deformities.
    • Outcome: Minor CTEV may self-correct this way.
  2. Manipulation + Plaster of Paris (POP) Casting
    • Kite's method:
      • Manipulate the foot, then apply an above-knee plaster cast.
      • Recasts every 2 weeks, progressing sequentially from cavus → adduction → varus → equinus.
      • Correction may take 6-9 months; about 30% achieve full correction non-operatively.
    • Ponseti's method:
      • Start within the first week of life.
      • Correct in the order: cavus → adduction → varus → equinus (CAVE sequence).
      • Weekly recasting; typically 5-7 casts over ~6 weeks.
      • Percutaneous Achilles tenotomy often needed under local anesthesia, with spontaneous tendon regeneration.
  3. Operative Treatment
    • Soft tissue release (e.g., Posteromedial Soft Tissue Release - PMSTR):
      • For infants under 3 years with deformities uncorrected by non-operative means or that recur.
      • Involves releasing contracted tendons, ligaments, and joint capsules.
    • Bony procedures:
      • Reserved for older children with neglected or previously treated CTEV.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dennis Browne splint (Option A)

  • A foot abduction brace used after initial correction with casting, not as a primary treatment in a 1-month-old.
  • It's worn long-term (nightly) to maintain correction, not to achieve it.

Serial taping by parents (Option C)

  • Part of the French method (taping and physiotherapy), which is more labor-intensive and less commonly used.
  • Not preferred over serial plaster casting initiated in the neonatal period.

CTEV shoes (Option D)

  • Also a maintenance tool, typically used once the child begins walking (>9-12 months).
  • Not appropriate at 1 month of age for initial correction.

questions.text: A 3-month-old male infant was treated for congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) using the Ponseti method. After serial casting and percutaneous tenotomy, the foot was fully corrected. The parents are now advised on long-term bracing. The orthopedic surgeon prescribes CTEV shoes to prevent recurrence. What is false about CTEV shoes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Medial arch support is used for flat foot.
  • CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equino Varus) shoes are bracing/maintenance devices used after correction of clubfoot deformity, usually following the Ponseti method or surgery. Their main function is to maintain correction and prevent relapse.
  • CTEV shoes are designed to avoid any medial arch support. Supporting the arch could encourage varus, which is counterproductive.
  • The features of CTEV shoes are
    • Straight medial border( Option A ruled out)
    • Lateral shoe raise( Option C ruled out)
    • Absent heel( Option D ruled out)
